description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The Government of Romania, through the Authority for the Digitization of Romania, and the non-governmental organization Code for Romania launched the online platform COVID-19 Official News (stirioficiale.ro) on Monday, 16.03.2020. The aim of this platform is to fight misinformation and fake news in order to rebuild trust with the state. The site only publishes reliable sources such as press releases from the Romanian government
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Romania’s President Klaus Iohannis declared a state of emergency across the country on March 16. One of its provisions gives the government power to remove from the public arena information considered to be false. 
The Centre for Independent Journalism, CJI, an NGO that promotes media freedom and good practices in journalism, has raised concern that provisions enacted as part of the state of emergency to combat the spread of the coronavirus in Romania could hamper journalists’ ability to inform the public.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The WHO Country Office in Ukraine conducted a social media campaign to raise awareness and highlight best practice. In Romania, more than 50 articles appeared in traditional media and a social media campaign was conducted in Romanian. WAAW in Romania also featured a strong partnership with both the Romanian Society for Microbiology and one of the main news platforms in the country – DC News. A lively online debate, moderated by a prominent health journalist, was held involving the WHO Representative in Romania, Dr Miljana Grbic, as well as professionals active in the field.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 10th, 2020, the Romanian Ministry of Health announce that the study programs of exchange type of experience and internships in hospitals of students and pupils of post-secondary health schools are stopped, if they were not started before March 9 this year. Postsecondary internships for medical students and experience programs for healthcare and sanitation workers are also suspended if they were not started before March 9.

description:
On April 27th 2020, Romanian President Klaus Iohannis stated in a press release by the National Liberal Party that schools would remain closed for most students until the end of the school year- June 12th 2020. Online learning would continue for these students.

Students in the 8th and 12th grades could come into school from the period of June 2nd to June 12th to prepare for national exams for high school and university. Class sizes were restricted to a maximum of 10 students, and they would only be at school for 3 hours a day, maximum. Exams would continue with social distancing measures observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: "The Romanian authorities are preparing for a scenario in which schools in the country will remain closed in September when the new school year will start. Courses could thus move online, and the local education system should be digitized by then, education minister Monica Anisie said in TV interviews over the weekend.  About 250,000 of the 3 million students enrolled in primary and secondary education in Romania don't have access to technology and can't participate in online courses, the education minister said at Digi24.  The Romanian authorities closed all schools and kindergartens in the country on March 11 to stop the spreading of the COVID-19 epidemic. The decision was enforced before the state of emergency was decreed in the country, on March 16.  On April 27, president Klaus Iohannis announced that schools would remain closed in Romania until the end of the school year."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: According to the approved calendar, on June 2, students from the VIIIth and XIIth grades will come to prepare for the national exams. As such, we have a situation, per school, of the number of students who have shown this agreement to come without endangering family members, themselves or those they come into contact with. The training will be daily, in each school, respecting the distancing rules and the latest orders that provide for the provision of a 4 square meter area for each student in the classrooms, after which, from June 15, the national exams begin. Not only the children, but also the teaching, teaching-auxiliary and non-teaching staff can safely come to school, all measures will be taken, the surfaces will be disinfected by a professional company and the school staff, the materials are provided, we have additional masks, parents should not have any fear in leaving their children at school during this period.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Brașov City Hall made the decision not to open pre-school education units - kindergartens and crèches, after consulting the normative acts in force, the analysis of the things that must be done to fulfill the conditions provided for in the joint order of the Ministries of Health, Education and Labor and Social Protection, and at the same time after consultations with the institutions that are involved in making this decision - the management of each educational unit, the County School Inspectorate and, most importantly, the Directorate of Public Health. In the Municipality of Brașov there are 8 nurseries and 27 state kindergartens.

description: Brașov City Hall made the decision not to open pre-school education units - kindergartens and nurseries, after consulting the normative acts in force, the analysis of the things that must be done to fulfill the conditions provided for in the joint order of the Ministries of Health, Education and Labor and Social Protection, and at the same time after consultations with the institutions that are involved in making this decision - the management of each educational unit, the County School Inspectorate and, most importantly, the Directorate of Public Health. In the Municipality of Brașov there are 8 nurseries and 27 state kindergartens. UPDATE: Starting from December 9, all 8 nurseries in the municipality of Brașov will resume their activity. Other units will remain closed.

description: Romanian schools scheduled to re-open from 14th September, 2020. Schools can use three learning models when the new school year starts, depending on each locality's coronavirus situation. The three scenarios are: in-person classes, the hybrid model (alternating virtual learning and in-class learning), and online/at-home only learning.

description: Romanian Ministry of Education and Research announced on 22nd of October, 2020, that 2401 education units are listed to work in red scenario (Scenario 3), involving the participation only in online activities. 4891 education units are listed in Scenario 2, meaning partial return (by rotation) in compliance with all rules of protection and 10364 in Scenario 1 (daily participation in compliance with all health protection rules).  According to the Order of the Minister of Education and Research and the Minister of Health 5487/1494/01.09.2020, one of the three operating scenarios is the cumulative incidence rate, respectively the total number of new cases in the last 14 days compared to 1000 inhabitants.

description: According to the Romanian ministerial order 5972/8.11.20, starting on 9.11.20, the teaching activities that require the physical presence of preschoolers and students in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for a period of 30 days. The teaching activities will be carried out online, according to the Framework Methodology on conducting teaching activities through technology and the Internet, as well as for the processing of personal data, approved by order of the Ministry of Education and Research 5545/2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting from December 9, all 8 nurseries in the municipality of Brașov will resume their activity. The operating hours of the nurseries will be from Monday to Friday, between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. In the last days, all the interior spaces of the 8 nurseries were cleaned and disinfected, so they are ready for the start of the activity.
During Monday and Tuesday, December 7-8, the 194 employees who work in nurseries were tested, using rapid antigen tests. Test results were negative for all employees. Rapid antigen tests provide results in a maximum of 15 minutes and are more than 95% accurate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

institution_conditions: Negative COVID-19 Test
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Starting with 11.01.2021; all educational activities that require physical presence at schools - primary; secondary and high school levels - are suspended until 7.02.2021 based on CNSU order 2/08.01.2021. Education activities will take place online. Update 3/02: From 8 February educational activities will restart with physical presence following 3 different scenarios depending on the incidence rate at local level (green scenario 14 days incidence rate <= 1/ 1000 pop. ; yellow scenario 14 days incidence rate is >1/ 1000 pop. but <=3/1000 pop.; and red scenario 14 days incidence rate is >3/1000 pop.). Students in the primary school are attending school in all three scenarios; exception only when there is quarantine imposed at local level.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

institution_status: Primary Schools closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: A decision on reopening the schools in Romania will be taken on February 2, 2021, after a review of the country's coronavirus situation, prime minister Florin Citu said on Tuesday, January 19. He also said that "if things remain as they are" when it comes to the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic in Romania, schools will reopen on February 8, under the conditions announced by president Klaus Iohannis.

description: Schools in Romania will reopen from 8-Feb-21 but under different scenarios according to their local epidemiological situations. Under the green scenario, which corresponds to an infection rate of under 1.5 per 1,000 inhabitants (over a 14-day period), all students return to school. In the yellow scenario (infection rate of between 1.5 and 3), only kindergarten and primary school (I-IV grades) pupils return to school together with students in the eighth and twelfth grades, who have to prepare for the national exams. In the red scenario (infection rate of over 3), only kindergartens and primary schools will stay open. Localities with infection rates of over 6 per 1,000 residents will remain under lockdown, with schools closed, according to the plan announced by president Iohannis.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Other Health Monitoring
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: According to the Romanian ministerial order no.3.235/93/04.02.2021, depending on the incidence rate by localities, the activity of the educational units will be organized, starting with 8th of February, in three scenarios: a) Physical presence for all categories, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days in the locality is less or equal to 1/1000 people; b) physical presence for preschool, primary, 8th, 12th and 13th classes, and online presence for the other classes, for a incidence less or equal with 3/1000; c) Online presence for all categories, except preschool and primary units, if incidence is higher than 3/1000.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: According to the Romanian ministerial order no.3755/29.04.2021 (which extends order no. 3235/93/2021), if the cumulative incidence of cases, in a locality for the last 14 days, is lower than 1/1000 inhabitants, the participation in classes will be physical presence for all preschoolers, primary school students and other groups of students. If it is higher than 1/1000, all activities will be online, except the students from grades 8th, 12th, and 13th classes.

description: Opening is based on three scenarios considering the epidemiological situation at local level. Scenario 1: all pupils in daycare; primary; secondary and higher education are attending classes in-person; respecting all protection norms Scenario 2: all pupils in daycare; primary and classes VIII and XII are attending classes; respecting all protection norms And partial attendance ( rotational schedule 1-2 weeks) of all others classes in the gymnasium; respecting all protection norms Scenario 3: all pupils will attend online.= Epi situation is assessed as follows based on the 14 days incidence rate: <1/ 1000 population ? scenarios 1 and 2 1-3/ 1000 population ? scenario 2 > 3/ 1000 population? scenario 3 (based on an assessment of community transmissions in the locality and if clusters in schools of that locality and risk criteria; can decide to suspend the activity in that school and go online; otherwise will use scenario 2). 13/06/2020: summer holidays for all schools; and despite school closures; this measure was still active.; 31/08/2020: summer holidays end.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions

description: Romania imposed a curfew starting on the 21st of March 2020. In the time interval 22.00 - 06.00, the movement of persons outside the household is allowed only for medical purposes, work, acquiring goods to cover basic needs- including those of pets, caring for a child/elderly person, short physical activity trips including walking pets.In order to verify the reason for traveling in the professional interest, the persons are obliged to present, at the request of the competent authorities staff, the service card, the certificate issued by the employer or a declaration on their own responsibility or a declaration on their own responsibility, completed in advance.The declaration on one's own responsibility must include the name and surname, date of birth, residential address/ place of professional activity, reason for travel, date of completion and signature.The exceptions to these provisions are the personnel within the Presidential Administration, the Romanian Parliament, the Romanian Government, the Public Ministry, the institutions of the national defense system, public order and national security, the diplomatic corps and the personnel providing public utility services.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Romania imposed a curfew starting on the 21st of March 2020. 
In the time interval 22.00 - 06.00, the movement of persons outside the household is allowed only for medical purposes, work, acquiring goods to cover basic needs- including those of pets, caring for a child/elderly person, short physical activity trips including walking pets.

In order to verify the reason for traveling in the professional interest, the persons are obliged to present, at the request of the competent authorities staff, the service card, the certificate issued by the employer or a declaration on their own responsibility or a declaration on their own responsibility, completed in advance.

The declaration on one's own responsibility must include the name and surname, date of birth, residential address/ place of professional activity, reason for travel, date of completion and signature.

The exceptions to these provisions are the personnel within the Presidential Administration, the Romanian Parliament, the Romanian Government, the Public Ministry, the institutions of the national defense system, public order and national security, the diplomatic corps and the personnel providing public utility services.

 UPDATE: The curfew was lifted on May 15th 2020
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Military,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Starting from February 19, 2021, Brașov returns to the restrictions from before February 3. Thus, nurseries and kindergartens will remain open, and only primary school students (grades 0-IV) will go to school, for the other grades school will be conducted entirely online.

Cultural institutions, cinemas, restaurants and cafes, gambling halls are closed again. The Opera, the Philharmonic, the Sică Alexandrescu Theater and the Arlechino Theater, institutions subordinate to the municipality, have suspended all their public performances scheduled for the next two weeks, returning the money for the paid tickets and switching to the online performance schedule.

description: As of  October 29 2020, Romanian state-owned airline Tarom will cancel several international and domestic flights because of the complicated current context. The company said that the flights to and from London would be suspended between November 7 and November 30. At the same time, the flights to and from Brussels are canceled on the days of November 2, 9, and 16, as are those to and from Munich on November 11, 18, and 25. The flights to and from Amsterdam are canceled on November 13, 20, 27, and December 4. The carrier also canceled several domestic flights. Those to and from Oradea are canceled on November 3, 5, 10, 12, 17, 19, 24, 25, and on December 1, 3, 8, 10, 15, while those to and from Satu Mare are canceled on November 4 and November 6. The company said it would contact those who purchased tickets on these dates to offer new flight dates.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Romania, February 12, 2021:
The National Committee for Emergency Situations declares that all persons arriving in Romania from countries/areas/territories with a "high epidemiological risk" shall present a certificate of a negative RT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 carried out no longer than 72 hours before the date of entry into the country. The countries/areas/territories currently affected by this measure can be found in the source document "Lista tarilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 6 din 04.02.2021 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Exempted from this measure are, among other things, children under 3 years of age and vaccinated people (see article 1 of the source document "HOTĂRÂRE nr. 7 din 04.02.2021"). The ending of this policy is indefinite.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: The Romanian National Committee for Emergency Situations (CNSU) updated the yellow list of countries with high epidemiological risk on 5 March 2021. Travelers arriving from these countries are required to quarantine upon entry for 14 days at home or a stated location. Fifty-two countries are on the list, including many European ones such as Spain, Italy, or the UK, where large communities of Romanians are found. The Republic of Moldova and the United States are also on the list, as is Bulgaria, a favorite tourism destination for many Romanians.

description: From the 19th of June 2020, the Ministry of Transport, Infrastructure and Communications in Romania is launching an application in which travellers entering Henri Coanda Airport, Bucharest have to fill out a questionnaire. This includes contact details and residence of isolation- if necessary. Travellers must then isolate for 10 days. This is targeted towards people travelling from areas of high epidemiological risk, but not to those with similar or less infection rates than Romania. After 10 days of quarantine, travellers are free to leave isolation.

description: By May 16, Romania registered approximately 10% of the total deaths caused by Covid-19 among residents in centres for older people and people with disabilities. There are 122 deaths due to COVID-19 registered in residential centres for older people and adults with disabilities, and no deaths among institutionalized children. Yet, 640 adults and 17 children are still infected, alongside 360 employees of the residential centres, and two registered deaths.

description: On the 21st of January 2020, the Technical-Scientific Support Group for the Management of Highly Contagious Diseases in Romania decided with the Ministry of Internal Affairs to order 1,750,000 protective resources, including PPE, single use gloves and protective masks. They also allocated 110 isolation rooms with negative pressure, 200 cardio respirator machines- 3 sets for the 57 emergency hospitals plus 9 Regional Centres of Infectious diseases, and 2 reserves. They also ordered 150 sets of filters for the isolated rooms, 9000 litres of disinfectant TP1, 9000 litres of TP 2, 5,100 kg of disinfectant for semicritical surfaces, and 5,100 kg of disinfectant for noncritical surfaces.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 26th of February 2020 Romanian Ministry of Health recommended people not take antiviral drugs or antibiotics unless prescribed by their doctor. They said that at the moment, there is no scientific research that shows that the use of antiviral drugs can prevent infection with the new coronavirus (Covid-19). Antibiotics only work against bacteria, not viruses. Thus, scientific research is needed.

description:
On March 11, 2020, the mayor made the decision to set up two quarantine centers, on the territory of the municipality of Brașov, with 31 rooms in total, in case situations arise that require the isolation of some people for whom it is necessary to take these measures. UPDATE: To equip the two quarantine centers, Brașov City Hall purchased: 200 quilts, 200 pillows, 200 elastic sheets, 200 single sheets, 50 hand towels, 350 bath towels, 100 coveralls, 600 pairs of surgical gloves, 10 boxes of disinfectant pills, 147 boxes of hand sanitizer.
In the next period, the following will arrive at these centers: 145 sensor dispensers, 225 hand gels, 21 boxes of surface disinfectant tablets, 400 pairs of pajamas, 200 pairs of slippers, 200 tubes of toothpaste, 200 toothbrushes, 10,000 masks, 10,000 pairs of gloves, 500 coveralls and 500 goggles.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: As of April 3, 2020, Brașov City Hall has started the distribution of disinfection solutions for common spaces in blocks of flats. Thus, the Municipality will make available to each association the necessary quantity for the disinfection of the access doors in the staircase of the block, the railings, the elevator, the pavement and the stairs, as well as to have an area, at the entrance to the block, with a solution for the disinfection of shoes. At the same time, the owners' associations will receive protective gloves and masks to ensure the disinfection operation on each staircase.

description: In Romania, the missions to transport medical equipment from South Korea have started. Approximately 45 tons of equipment, consisting of 100 thousand protective suits, will be brought to the country, between April 13 and 17, 2020, with transport aircraft belonging to the Romanian Air Force. The equipment was purchased from South Korea by the Romanian state, through the National Centralized Procurement Office and the General Inspectorate for Emergency Situations, as part of efforts to combat the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and will be allocated, depending on needs, to medical personnel from the country and operative crews acting in the field.

description:
On February 4 and 5. 2021, Brașov City Hall is carrying out the disinfection activity of the educational institutions that will open from February 8, as part of the municipality's action program to ensure hygienic-sanitary conditions for the prevention of diseases and the prevention of the transmission of SARS-CoV-2.

Disinfection is done with the Huwa-San TR 50 product, produced in Belgium and approved by the Ministry of Health. 

All the premises of the educational institutions in Brașov will be disinfected, with the exception of the Secondary School No. 1 on Cocorului street.

Disinfection is carried out with five teams. On February 4, 33 kindergartens, 6 schools and 4 high schools are scheduled, and on February 5, the remaining 6 kindergartens, 13 schools and 18 high schools, to which nursery school no. 7 is added, will be disinfected.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Romania is ranked as a country with a high number of hospital beds, but the real concern is how many ICU beds are equipped with ventilators. The authorities have reported that out of around 4,000 ICU beds only about half are equipped with ventilators. Measures have been taken to increase the number of ventilators by both international procurement and national production. Of the 350 million (approximately 74.5 million euros) that the Government has released to manage the COVID-19 outbreak, 209 million lei (approximately 44.5 million euros) has been allocated to ICU departments. Despite this, on the 1st of November 2020, the Minister of Health declared that only 1250 beds were allocated for COVID-19 patients, with plans to increase the capacity to 1500 ICU bed. This means close to doubling the number of ICU beds for COVID-19 patients compared to March, when the number of such beds was 740.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Romania, as of 20 February 2021, individuals with symptoms should call a family doctor who will make a telephone assessment and decide the way forward. If the doctor decides that a COVID-19 test is needed, the individual will be instructed to call the Public Health Directorate and mention all symptoms. The ambulance service will go to the individual’s house to perform the test, or if the situation requires it, will transport the individual to the hospital. In the case of symptomatic people, the test is done according to the protocol, free of charge. Individuals can also get tested "on request", but this option is for a fee.

description: On the 10th of June 2021, the Romanian Ministry of Health provides a list of accredited facilities in Romania certified for RT-PCT COVID-19 testing facilities which will prioritize tests for hospitalized patients, individuals suspected of being infected with COVID-19, and individuals who are in a high-risk group. Depending on their availability, they may perform testing on demand and may set the cost of the tests performed on demand. The cost of COVID-19 testing on demand varies between $70 – $100. Test results are delivered by email and text message. Positive test results are also included in the database of the Romanian Department of Public Health.

description:
In Romania, on the 1st of March 2020, the Ministry of Health declared hygiene regulations to prevent the spread of Covid-19:
- People should frequently disinfect the surfaces they come in contact with, with alcohol or chlorine solution, both at home and at work. 
- Avoid touching surfaces that are frequently touched by other people, such as railings, doorknobs, handles, elevators, or access buttons. If they do have to touch these surfaces, protect by using disposable wipes. -- 
- Wash hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds after any contact with a potentially contaminated surface. 
- Use paper towels, preferably, to wipe hands. 
- Do not touch your eyes, nose or mouth with unsanitized hands. 
- If sneeze or cough, cover your mouth and nose with a disposable tissue, which you should dispose of in the trash immediately.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Government of Romania responded early to the pandemic. In January 2020, the National Centre for the Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases published information about the new virus on its website, including information on transmission and measures to prevent infection. The first measures that were communicated were: hygiene practices (including on washing hands correctly, coughing, and sneezing), physical distancing, and symptoms where people should ask for medical advice or share information on recent trips abroad. There were also tips for people returning from affected areas, namely that if they had any symptoms, they should contact airport medical staff immediately or, if symptoms emerged within 14 days of their journey, they should wear protective masks and call the emergency number
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: During the State of Alert, wearing a face mask is mandatory in all indoor public spaces, commercial spaces, working spaces and public transport. Exceptions include children under 5, people with medical conditions that affect their respiratory capacity, people working solitarily in an office. Hands disinfection and triage at the entrance are mandatory. Individuals with body temperature higher than 37.5 (measured twice) are not allowed to enter the building and are referred immediately to the family doctor (GP).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: 25/03/2020 People older than 65 required to stay at home all day except between 07:00 - 11:00 when they can go out for selected; restricted activities. ; Military Ordinance no.10/27.04.2020: People over 65 are allowed to leave home between 07:00 - 11:00 and 19:00-22:00 for activities restricted to shopping; caring for a minor or elder; household/gardening activities and individual walks. *exception medical assistance; professional activities. Commercial operators selling food or other essential products will ensure priority access of elderly people (> 65) during 07:00-11:00 and 19:00-22:00.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)

description:
Romania, March 30, 2020:
The Ministry of Internal Affairs imposes a zonal quarantine on the municipality of Suceava and the surrounding area consisting of the following eight municipalities: Adâncata, Salcea, Ipotești, Bosanci, Moara, Șcheia, Pătrăuți and Mitocu Dragomirnei. Exceptions for entering/exiting this locality exist. Reuters: "The quarantine will last until mid-April at the end of the 30-day emergency period". The state of emergency is slated to end on April 15.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Suceava; Adâncata; Salcea; Ipotești; Bosanci; Moara; Șcheia; Pătrăuți; Mitocu Dragomirnei.

description: Romania issued a military ordinance, to enforce a lockdown, as all citizens were forbidden from traveling outside of their homes unless it is for professional purposes or the purchase of essential goods (with several other smaller exceptions). UPDATE: from May 15th, citizens could leave their homes but only travel within their localities. UPDATE: From May 15th 2020, Romania went from a state of emergency to a state of alert, and self-declaration forms will no longer be needed to leave the house
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: "[Q:] Do people over the age of 65 have any restrictions on leaving the house or any time slot they have to follow?  [A:] CNSSU decision no. 24 regarding the declaration of the state of alert does not restrict the movement of persons over 65 years of age. They can leave home at any time they wish. However, the recommendation to limit travel as much as possible and to avoid crowded places, especially for people in vulnerable categories, in order to reduce the risk of infection with the new Coronavirus, remains valid."

description: The County Capital of Szatmár County, Szatmárnémeti (Satu Mare), will be placed under lockdown starting on November 18, 2021, after the coronavirus infection rate in the city reached 7.4 per 1,000 residents in the last 14 days. Szatmárnémeti will be placed under quarantine for 14 days, along with Szatmárpálfalva (Păulești), Vetés (Vetiș) and Szaniszló (Sanislău), where the infection rate has also been high.

description: On 29th November 2021, Romania is set to help evacuate dozens of Europeans stranded in South Africa. A repatriation plane left Bucharest on Monday morning to bring home 40 Romanian citizens who are trapped in the area. It comes as Europe restricts flights from southern Africa after the detection of the new COVID variant Omicron.

description: On 10 March 2022, health-care provision is organized by Romania to refugees from Ukraine. description: On 11th February 2021, the Government of Romania defined “close contact” with COVID-19-infected individuals to facilitate epidemiological investigations. The purpose of defining close contact is to identify individuals designated for 14-day self-isolation following close contact with a COVID-19-confirmed infection. During the period of self-isolation, “close contact” individuals will be tested at the beginning and end of the two-week period. The epidemiological investigation should not lead to the supervised isolation of other individuals not meeting “close contact” criteria.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 13th of July 2021, in Romania, everyone who tests positive for coronavirus will be put in touch with an NHS contact tracer to help identify who they’ve been in close contact with. Mobile contact tracing app is also another possibility but it's not in operation now.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting on 25th February 2020, an online public information campaign was launched on the official Government of Romania Facebook page on the "Prevention and limitation of eventual infection with coronavirus". New, updated information has since been provided daily on the facebook page ( https://www.facebook.com/guv.ro) On the 24/02/2020, this campaign was announced: "The information campaign of the population regarding the infection with COVID-19 will be extended, as well as the individual and collective prevention measures which should be taken and a daily newscast will be drafted regarding the development at international level and possible additional measures taken by the Romanian authorities"

description: In Romania, as of the 21st of July 2020, the TELVERDE line number is functioning, which is a telephone line strictly allocated for informing citizens and is valid for national calls, from Monday to Friday, between 08.00 and 20.00. Government reminds citizens to consider only information verified through official sources and to call for recommendations and other information on the TELVERDE line – 0800.800.358. Romanians abroad can request information about preventing and combating the virus at the line specially dedicated to them, +4021.320.20.20.

description: On the 14th of October 2020, Romanian authorities extend the COVID-19 state of alert until the 15th of November 2020. Under the state of alert, the wearing of face masks remains mandatory on public transport and in enclosed public spaces, such as stores.

description: On 20th 2021, Earlier this week, representatives of WHO/Europe and the WHO Country Office in Romania met with senior officials from the National Coordination Committee on Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 (CNCAV), the Ministry of Health and the National Centre for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases. They discussed the current trend in COVID-19 vaccination uptake and considered pragmatic evidence-informed actions to rapidly scale up efforts to address this. In close coordination with the government and Ministry of Health, WHO/Europe will work closely with stakeholders to promote training opportunities and information exchange between health-care professionals on vaccine safety, as well as devise communication strategies that will improve understanding of the reasons behind low vaccination uptake in certain population groups.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 25th of October 2020, the Romanian Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic” to spread public awareness. On the 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infectious diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their homes. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases.

description: On 18 January 2021, WHO is working with Romania’s Ministry of Health and health professionals in the country to make telephone consultations more widely available. The aim is to institutionalize telemedicine in Romania and make the service easily accessible to patients during and after the pandemic. WHO supported a proposal by the Ministry’s Paediatric Commission to update national health legislation to include phone triage, thereby helping to strengthen health services in the wake of COVID-19.

description: As of 20th February 2021, the Romanian official government website for COVID-19 remains current. Daily updates, press releases, current restrictions, statistics, educational videos, hygiene recommendations, advice for parents, and answers to frequently asked questions are provided on the website. Individuals can also subscribe to an official email newsletter for updates and important information. The purpose of the extensions is to highlight official sources of information in order to reduce the effects of 'fake news'. The extension identifies key phrases related to COVID-19 and adds an info box that links to official sources    RoVaccinare is the official platform for information regarding vaccination against COVID-19 in Romania (vaccinare-covid.gov.ro). The website provides news, information on authorized vaccines, the vaccination process in Romania, and corrects misinformation surrounding vaccines.     Additional information is also provided on the Ministry of Health’s website (www.ms.ro/coronavirus-covid-19).

description: On 19 April 2021, In Romania, a chain of care has been established to link charitable organizations working with people living on the streets with health authorities, ensuring that homeless people with underlying health issues have been able to access vaccines. description:
Romania, February 5, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Argentina, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Georgia, Germany, Gibraltar, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Panama, Poland, Portugal, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Sint Maarten, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States of America, Lebanon, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Albania, Guernsey, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Bolivia, Eswatini, Maldives, Kosovo, Tunisia, Falkland Islands, Peru, Belarus, Cape Verde, Russia, Dominican Republic, North Macedonia, Kuweit and Malaysia. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On February 11, 2021, Dominican Republic, Tunisia, Cape Verde, Canada and Russia are removed from the list of yellow zone countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Romania, February 24, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese provinces of Hubei (including the cities of Hubei and Wuhan) and Zhejiang (explicitly the cities of Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou); the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy (explicitly the localities of Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano); Cumiana in the Italian Piedmont region. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (institutionalized quarantine). Those from other places in mainland China and the Lombardy and Veneto regions need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The policy has no explicit end date.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou (Zhejiang); Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano (Lombardy/Veneto); Cumiana (Piedmont)

description:
Romania, March 11, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese province of Hubei; Italy; the South Korean city of Daegu and county of Cheongdo; the French regions of Hauts de France, Ile de France, Grand Est, Bourgogne France Comte and Auvergne Rhones Alpes; the German regions of Baden-Wuerttemberg, Bavaria and Nordrhein Westfalen; the Spanish region of Madrid. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). Additionally, those from Iran as well as other places in South Korea, mainland China, France, Germany and Spain need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: From March 15, the red zone countries/regions are:
   
   - China - Hubei Region
   - Italy
   - Daegu and Cheongdo (Gyeongsangbuk-do - South Korea)
   - Iran
   
   ... the yellow zone countries/regions are:
   
   - Austria
   - Belgium
   - all other places in South Korea
   - Denmark
   - Switzerland
   - France
   - Germany
   - Japan
   - Great Britain
   - Norway
   - Netherlands
   - all other places in China
   - Spain
   - USA
   - Sweden

The current yellow zone countries are: Australia; Austria; Belgium; Brazil; Canada; Czech Republic; Chile; all other places in South Korea and China; Denmark; Ecuador; Switzerland; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Iceland; Indonesia; Ireland; Israel; Japan; Malaysia; UK; Norway; Netherlands; Pakistan; Poland; Portugal; Saudi Arabia; Spain; USA; Sweden; Turkey. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: From March 25, the red zone countries are: Italy, France, Germany, Spain, Iran. The remaining countries of the world are now treated as yellow zone countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
Romania, March 27, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) declares that, should HCW [health-care workers; W.H.] come into contact with confirmed cases and they do not present with symptoms, they are asked to self-isolate at home [for 14 days; W.H.] without a test. description: Retail activities of products and services in shopping malls remain closed, except for (a) small shopping centres (under 15,000 sqm, with individual shops on the premises of less than 500 sqm each); (b) home delivery of electronic and household products; (c) retail centres with direct access from the street; (d) the agri-food stores, pharmacies, dental offices, lens medical service centres, dry cleaning services and beauty parlours. Indoor and outdoor restaurants and coffee-shops remain closed (Law 55/15.05.2020 on the State of Alert/Government Decision 394/18.05.2020).

Also, some new exceptions are added according to article 1, numbers 3 and 4 of the source document "ORDIN nr. 1.080 din 12 iunie 2020".

description: From 11th August 2020, travellers from Spain will be placed in a 14 day quarantine in Romania. The place of quarantine will either be the person's home, at a location declared by him or, as the case may be, in a special space designated by the authorities. Quarantine is recommended to all people who live at the same address.

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: South Africa, Argentine, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Turks and Caicos Islands, United States Virgin Islands, Iraq, Israel, Kazhakstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Maldives, Moldavia, Montenegro, Palestine, Panama, Peru, Puerto Rico, Qatar, Dominican Republic, United States of America, Suriname, Bahamas, Sint Maarten, Aruba, Faroe Islands, Eswatini, Guam, Malta, Belize and 6 regions in Spain (Aragon, Catalonia, Navarra, Community of Madrid, Balearic Islands, Basque Country). Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Czech Republic, Luxembourg, French Polynesia, Slovenia, Armenia, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, France, Croatia, Georgia, Guam, Poland, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Austria, Montenegro, San Marino, Italy, Portugal, Northern Macedonia, Jordan, Hungary, Bulgaria, Lithuania and Denmark. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On November 21, Serbia and the US are added to the list of yellow zone countries.

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Czech Republic, Luxembourg, French Polynesia, Slovenia, Armenia, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Croatia, Georgia, Austria, Montenegro, San Marino, Portugal, Northern Macedonia, Jordan, Hungary, Bulgaria, Lithuania, Denmark, Serbia, the US, Curaçao, Sweden, Belize, Jersey, Panama, Palestine, Azerbaijan, Puerto Rico, Netherlands, Cyprus, Slovakia, Turkey, Moldavia, Latvia, Estonia, UK and Northern Ireland. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On December 25, French Polynesia, Austria, Armenia, Jordan are removed from the list of yellow zone countries while Gibraltar, Sint Maarten and South Africa are added.

description: Those coming to Romania from any other destination will be placed under home isolation for 14 days. From 25/03/20 - 24/06/20: Anyone coming in Romania from Italy; Spain; France; Germany; and Iran will be placed under quarantine in a state facility for a period of 14 days. UPDATE 15/06/2020: Asymptomatic travellers coming from green countries are not required to quarantine/isolate. List of low risk countries to be updated regularly.

The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Argentina, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Colombia, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Georgia, Germany, Gibraltar, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Panama, Poland, Portugal, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Sint Maarten, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States of America, Lebanon, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Albania, Guernsey, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Bolivia, Eswatini, Maldives, Kosovo, Falkland Islands, Peru, Belarus, Dominican Republic, North Macedonia, Kuweit and Malaysia. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On February 15, 2021, Moldova, Botswana, French Polynesia, Qatar and Hungary are added to the list of yellow zone countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_country: Albania,Andorra,Argentina,Austria,Bahrain,Belarus,Belgium,Bolivia,Brazil,Chile,Colombia,Cyprus,Czechia,Estonia,Eswatini,France,Georgia,Germany,Ireland,Israel,Italy,Kosovo,Kuwait,Latvia,Lebanon,Liechtenstein,Lithuania,Luxembourg,Malaysia,Maldives,Malta,Monaco,Montenegro,Netherlands,North Macedonia,Other (please specify below),Panama,Peru,Poland,Portugal,Saint Lucia,Saint Vincent and the Grenadines,San Marino,Serbia,Seychelles,Slovakia,Slovenia,South Africa,Spain,Sweden,Switzerland,United Arab Emirates,United Kingdom,United States,Uruguay
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Every person arriving in Romania from a country with high epidemiological risk must undergo a mandatory quarantine. The list of countries is periodically updated by the National Committee for Special Emergency Situations led by the Prime Minister (the list was last updated on February 19, 2021). At present, every person without a negative RT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 that was taken less than 72 hours before their arrival in Romania must remain in quarantine for 14 days. However, people arriving into Romania from countries with high epidemiological risk who present a negative RT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 that was taken within 72 hours prior to arrival and children under 3 years old must only quarantine for 10 days.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting on February 24, a 14-day mandatory quarantine was imposed for people returning from mainland China (Hubei Province) and twelve localities in Italy, along with a 14-day self-isolation period at home for people returning from other provinces/cities in mainland China and other localities from the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States of America, Lebanon, St. Lucia, Albania, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Maldives, Peru, Dominican Republic, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Qatar, Hungary, Antigua and Barbuda, Barbados, Jordan, Palestine, Bulgaria, Kosovo and Paraguay. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On March 14, 2021, Antigua and Barbuda, Barbados, Paraguay, Qatar and the US are removed from the list of yellow zone countries while Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Isle of Man and Liechtenstein are added.

description: Starting on March 24, a 14-day isolation or quarantine was imposed on all people returning from abroad. Disobeying home isolation falls under the civil or penal codes, and the authorities have reinforced the penalties through a Governmental Ordinance. A national map with the number of cases, including the numbers of population in quarantine or isolation, is updated in real-time.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovenia South Africa, Sweden, Lebanon, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Hungary, Jordan, Palestine, Bulgaria, Kosovo, Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Moldova, Territory of Wallis and Futuna Islands, Curaçao, Armenia, Bermuda, Croatia, Turkey, Ukraine, Isle of Man and Puerto Rico. Individuals from these countries are to be quarantined for 14 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.

description:
Romania, May 14, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries/regions are labelled as red zone countries: Seychelles, Maldives, Bahrain, Uruguay, Cyprus, Cape Verde, Argentina, Lithuania, Costa Rica, Netherlands, Sweden, Croatia, Turkey, Latvia, Colombia, Andorra, Georgia, Puerto Rico, Mongolia, Slovenia, Paraguay, Kuwait, France, Chile, India, Brazil, Estonia, Belgium, Luxembourg, Nepal, Serbia, South Africa. The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries:Iran, Canada, Qatar, Germany, Greece, Montenegro, Switzerland, Peru, United Arab Emirates, Trinidad and Tobago, Italy, Austria, Anguilla, Czech Republic, Bahamas, Oman, Hungary, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Guyana, Aruba, Denmark, Armenia, Spain, Poland, Palestine, Iraq, Liechtenstein, Bulgaria, Suriname, Bolivia, USA, Lebanon, Tunisia, North Macedonia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Belarus. Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.

description:
Romania, May 10, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovenia South Africa, Sweden, Lebanon, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Hungary, Jordan, Bulgaria, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Curaçao, Armenia, Bermuda, Croatia, Turkey, Ukraine, Puerto Rico, Argentina, Azerbaidjan, Canada, Cape Verde, Columbia, Costa Rica, Switzerland, Georgia, Germany, Greece, Iran, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Maldives, Mongolia, Oman, Paraguay, Peru, Qatar, US, Anguilla, Bahamas, Belarus, Bolivia, Denmark, Ecuador, United Arab Emirates, Guyana, India, Irak, Kazahstan, Monaco, Nepal, Palestina, Spain, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago and Tunisia. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On May 14, 2021, countries are again classified into red zone (where the cumulative incidence rate of new cases of illness in the last 14 days per 1,000 inhabitants is greater than or equal to 3 per 1,000 inhabitants), yellow zone (...between 1,5 and 3 per 1 000 inhabitants) and green zone (...less than or equal to 1.5) countries. For persons arriving from green zone countries, no quarantine measures shall be imposed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Travellers arriving from countries classified as "yellow", who do not provide a pre-departure negative PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival, and "red" are subject to a 14-day quarantine.

The quarantine period may be shortened by taking a PCR test no less than 8 days after arrival. If the result of this test is negative, the period of quarantine can end on day 10.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Romania, July 1, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries/regions are labelled as red zone countries: Argentina, Bahrain, Botswana, Brazil, Chile, Columbia, Costa Rica, India, Kuwait, Maldives, Mongolia, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Panama, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Seychelles, South Africa, Suriname, Tunisia, United Kingdom, Uruguay. The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries: Bolivia, British Virgin Islands, Cuba, Cyprus, Fiji, Georgia, Guyana, Iran, Iraq, Jersey, Kyrgyzstan, Malaysia, Portugal, Russian Federation, Sint Maarten, Trinidad and Tobago, United Arab Emirates, Zambia. Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries: Bolivia, Botswana, Chile, Faroe Islands, Gibraltar, Greece, Iran, Iraq, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Libya, Luxembourg, Paraguay, Russian Federation, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Trinidad and Tobago, United Arab Emirates, United States Virgin Islands, Uruguay. UPDATE: On July 25, 2021, the list of red and yellow zone countries was updated.

The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries/regions are labelled as red zone countries: Andorra, Argentina, Aruba, Bahamas, Botswana, Brazil, British Virgin Islands, Cuba, Curaçao, Cyprus, Eswatini, Fiji, France, French Polynesia, Georgia, Gibraltar, Greece, Iceland, India, Iran, Iraq, Ireland, Isle of Man, Jersey, Kazakhstan, Kuwait, Libya, Malaysia, Maldives, Malta, Monaco, Mongolia, Nepal, Netherlands, Panama, Portugal, Seychelles, South Africa, Spain, Thailand, Tunisia, United Kingdom, United States Virgin Islands. The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries: Belgium, Columbia, Costa Rica, Denmark, Guatemala, Honduras, Indonesia, Israel, Kyrgyzstan, Luxembourg, Montenegro, Morocco, Namibia, Oman, Puerto Rico, Russian Federation, Sint Maarten, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, Turkey, United Arab Emirates, United States of America, Zimbabwe. pentru Situații de Urgență". Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.

description:
On 5th November 2021, passengers traveling with only a negative PCR test and without a valid vaccination certificate or a certificate of recovery from COVID-19 to Bulgaria from Romania will be subject to 10 days of quarantine.

 UPDATE: On 27th November 2021, Approved travelers arriving in Romania from the above countries must quarantine for 14 days and undergo a PCR test upon arrival and on the 8th day of quarantine. If the second test is negative they may end quarantine on the 10th day.

description:
Romania, December 10, 2021:
The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they can't submit a negative test result upon arrival. The quarantine duration may be shortened to 10 days. In some cases, individuals are exempted from the quarantine obligation. The policy ends on January 8, 2022. Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
In Romania on the 6th of December 2021, Romania’s National Committee for Emergency Situations (CNSU), approved the rules (Decision 111/06.12.2021) for placing under quarantine those arriving in the country. The rules are valid between December 10 and January 8.

Those arriving from the European Union, European Economic Area or Switzerland, if they come from a Red zone, they are subject to 14-day quarantine if they have no vaccination certificate or proof of having recovered from Covid-19. Those unvaccinated or without proof of having recovered from the illness are subject to a 10-day quarantine if they hold an RT-PCR test taken less than 72 hours before the entry.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People who have recovered and/or survived COVID-19,People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Romania, December 5, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On December 10, 2021, persons arriving from Member States of the European Union, the European Economic Area or the Swiss Confederation are subject to different quarantine obligations compared to those from third-party countries. Third country nationals are to be quarantined if they do not submit a negative result of an RT-PCR test for COVID-19 carried out not more than 48 hours before boarding (for those travelling by public transport) or entering the national territory (for those travelling by their own means). Individuals from the EU, the EEA or Switzerland can also avert to be quarantined if they are vaccinated against or have recovered from COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Romania, December 10, 2021:
The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they can't submit a negative test result upon arrival. The quarantine duration may be shortened to 10 days. In some cases, individuals are exempted from the quarantine obligation. The policy ends on January 8, 2022. Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions. UPDATE: Based on DECISION no. 113 of 10.12.2021, individuals from third countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19 and are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from it. These individuals, if they are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19, are to be quarantined for 10 days if they are tested negative for COVID-19. If vaccinated or recovered, they are to be quarantined for 10 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19 and are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from it. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista țărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 115 din 17.12.2021 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions. UPDATE: From December 23, 2021, additional exceptions to the quarantine obligation are introduced according to the source document.

description:
Romania, January 9, 2022:
The National Emergency Committee declares that persons arriving in Romania from
countries/territories at epidemiological risk as well as direct contacts of confirmed persons are to be quarantined upon arrival:
a) 10 days for unvaccinated persons or persons who are not in the period between
the 11th to the 180th day after the date of confirmation of SARS-CoV-2 infection;
b) 5 days for vaccinated persons for whom 10 days have passed since the completion of
the vaccination scheme, and for persons who have been confirmed for SARS-CoV-2 infection SARS-CoV-2 virus between the 11th and the 180th day before the date of entry into the country or contact with the infected person. 
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions at epidemiological risk. The countries/regions labelled as red, yellow and green zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista țărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 2 din 07.01.2022 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Red, yellow and green zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. The end of this policy isn't mentioned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

Romania, February 1, 2022:

description: RATBv, the transport operator, will implement a series of measures aimed at limiting travelers' contact with employees, with banknotes and with machines positioned in areas with a high flow of travelers. Starting from March 14, 2020, access to public transport for passengers at the first door will be restricted, both for boarding and alighting, in the case of transport that does not have a closed cabin for the driver. Starting tomorrow, RATBV drivers will no longer sell paper tickets on any bus on any route. In the shortest possible time, the possibility to purchase monthly subscription(s) through the 24pay application, with the help of the mobile phone and the QR codes located in the means of transport, will be introduced in the tariff plan.

description: In order to reduce the risks of the spread of the COVID-19 virus, starting from March 19 the 2019-2020 ski season is considered closed. description: From May 15th 2020 in Romania, private businesses/ economic operators are obliged to ensure that employers can work from home. If the work can not be performed from home then employers must not allow the access of the persons whose body temperature, measured at the entrance to the enclosure exceeds 37.3 degrees. Employers must enforce mandatory disinfection of hands before entering work spaces, and disinfection of surfaces.

description: As of 15 February, the ban on indoor operation for bars, clubs, and disco activities remains in place. Cinemas, performance institutions, indoor restaurants, indoor cafés, and gambling halls are allowed to operate under the following conditions: Without exceeding 50% of the maximum capacity of the space and only in the time interval 6.00-23.00, in the counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5/1,000 inhabitants. Without exceeding 30% of the maximum capacity of the space and only in the time interval 6.00-23.00, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of the cases in the county/locality is higher than 1.5 and less than or equal to 3/1,000 inhabitants. It is forbidden if the cumulative incidence of cases is higher than 3/1,000 inhabitants. Currently, the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is over 3 per 1,000 occupants in Timis and Maramures counties, therefore, cinemas, performance institutions, indoor restaurants, indoor cafés, and gambling halls are closed in these counties.     Museums, art galleries, libraries, and bookstores are open with social distancing and mask requirements. Disinfection of hands and a temperature check is required before entering.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On March 11, 2020, Mayor George Scripcaru made a new appeal to the residents of Brasov to reduce their trips to the town hall or to other public institutions, in the context of measures to avoid the spread of the coronavirus. The City Council was asked to extend the deadline for paying local taxes by another month, during which the usual 5% bonus will also be granted, so that the residents of Brasov who cannot make payments online can postpone the payment them. The public work schedule of the City Hall and of the Fiscal Directorate have been modified.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
1. Starting from March 25, it is prohibited to carry out recreational activities in the places set up in the parks of the municipality of Brașov (the areas set up for the practice of collective games – chess, backgammon, rummy, etc.), but also in the other areas of the park. Only crossing them is allowed. It is Schaeffler Park - Livada Postei, Titulescu Park, Aleea de sub Tâmpa, Magnolia Park - civic center, Trandafirilor Park, Ursul Park, Berzei Park (Someșul), Lac Noua Park, Tractorul Park, Pasaj Fartec.
2. Starting from March 25, the use of the 204 public playgrounds, fitness areas, workout areas, skateboard and bicycle parks and sports fields in the municipality of Brașov is prohibited.
3. Starting from March 25, the use of places specially arranged for picnic activities is prohibited. This is the La Iepure area, the Pietrele lui Solomon area and the one at Lacul Noua. The same ban applies to any picnic activity on the public domain of the municipality of Brașov
4. Starting from March 24, the program with the public at the Zoo is suspended.
5. Starting from March 24, access to the Regina Maria multi-storey car park is suspended, except for people who have a subscription for this car park".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the government service is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
Starting October 25, 2021, public access to the premises of Brașov City Hall and its departments and services subordinate to the City Council is allowed only to people who provide proof of vaccination, passing through the disease in the last 180 days or testing, verified by means of the EU digital certificate regarding COVID-19, which will be scanned by their own staff.
In the case of RT-PCR testing, the negative result must not be more than 72 hours old, and in the case of a rapid antigen test, the result must not be more than 48 hours old.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

UPDATE: For urgent situations (for example: issuing a certificate of death, birth certificate) it is not necessary to present a green certificate, a proof that the person in question is in the period between the 15th and 180th day after the confirmation of infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus or a result negative in one of the COVID-19, RT-PCR or antigen tests.
