description:
Romania banned all mass gatherings of over 100 people from the 11th March 2020 until the 31st of March 2020, with the possibility of prolonging. This includes gatherings for sport, religious, scientific or leisure events. Indoor spaces such as theatres and cinemas were closed, but not shopping malls. 

This decision was announced by the head of the Department of Emergency Situations (DSU), Raed Arafat and Health Minister Nelu Tataru.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The outdoor cultural events (concerts) are allowed, but only if they respect of safety rules and sports competitions can be organized outdoors or at indoor pools but without spectators due to the extended state of alert by the Romanian government from August 16, 2020, to September 15, 2020. UPDATE: UPDATE: The state of alert on the entire territory of Romania is extended by 30 days until October 15. Private events in open spaces up to a maximum of 100 people are allowed, provided the observance of physical distancing applies. The organization of outdoor public meetings, rallies and demonstrations with a maximum number of 100 participants and provided compliance with the following measures: Mask mearing by all participants as to cover the nose and mouth; Mandatory disinfection of the hands, for all the persons who arrive in the space where they are conducts the rally or demonstration; Maintaining the physical distance of at least 1 meter between the participants and ensuring an area of minimum 4 sqm / person where possible; Disinfection of the hands of the persons who distribute any materials during the rally or demonstration.

description: Authorities of Romanian counties, Hunedoara, Bacău and Lași impose restrictions of mass gatherings in the Horeca area, after the end of the local elections. In Hunedoara county, in 12 localities, the operation of restaurants and bars is no longer allowed. In Bacău county, similar measures were taken in several localities, as well as in Iași county. The restrictions come in the context in which in several localities in the counties the infection rate of 1.5 / 1000 inhabitants has been exceeded in the last two weeks. The measures were taken at the central level and cover the whole country. Additionally, mass gathering events, such as concerts, cultural events, and gambling activities were either prohibited or subjected to curfew (shortened business hours).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

Additionally, mass gathering events, such as concerts, cultural events, and gambling activities were either prohibited or subjected to curfew (shortened business hours).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On October 5, 2020, Romania announced that "the organization of religious holidays is allowed only with the participation of persons who have their domicile or residence in the locality where the activity takes place, without the participation of persons / pilgrims from other localities."

CNSU decided to limit the attendance to religious events and celebrations amid growing COVID-19 infection cases. Only locals will be allowed to attend religious events held in Romanian localities. This includes the banning of religious pilgrimages. This decision comes prior to the largest pilgrimage in Romania to Lasi which will begin 08-Oct and reach its peak at 14-Oct. Currently no restrictions on free movement in Romania.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
It is forbidden to organize private events (weddings, baptisms, festive meals, etc.) in all spaces in Braşov county, such as, but not limited to: salons, cultural hostels, restaurants, bars , cafes, event halls/tents.

Recreational and sports activities carried out in the open air in Braşov County are prohibited, except for those carried out with the participation of no more than 10 people who do not live together, established by joint order of the Minister of Health, as the case may be, with the Minister of Youth and Sports, the Minister environment, water and forests or the minister of agriculture and rural development.

Participation in religious processions and/or pilgrimages in Braşov county is prohibited for persons who do not have their domicile or residence in the localities where these activities are carried out (art. 6).

description: The organization and outdoor performance of shows, concerts, public and private festivals or other cultural events is allowed in counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.     Events are limited to 300 spectators with seats located at a distance of at least 2 meters apart. Protective masks are also required.    Activities are prohibited in counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is higher than 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.    Currently the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is higher than 1.5/1,000 occupants in Timis, Maramures, Cluj, Brasov, Ilfov, Bucharest, Alba, Hunedoara, Satu Mare, Sibiu, Salaj, and Gorj counties.

description: According to Order 29/14.05.2021 of the Government of Romania, cultural, artistic and entertainment activities can be organized in open spaces with the participation of up to 1000 people, with a minimum area of 2 m2 for each person and compliance with health protection measures if the incidence of 14 days of cases in the county/locality is less than or equal to 3/1000 inhabitants. Sport competitions in open spaces can have up to 25% of the maximum capacity. Competitions with public participation in enclosed spaces is still forbidden. The policy is in place for the duration of the state of alert. The state of alert is slated to end on June 11, 2021.

description: Authorities in Romania have eased several domestic COVID-19-related restrictions on June 1, 2021. Outdoor gatherings are limited to 1,000 persons. Limitations on attendance at indoor gatherings including concerts, weddings and other cultural, leisure, or religious activities, have been lifted provided all the attendees are vaccinated. Gyms, fitness centres, museums, public swimming pools, and restaurants may operate at 70 per cent capacity.   Private events (weddings, baptisms, and birthdays) may accommodate a maximum of 70 guests outdoor, 50 guests indoor, or unlimited guests if those attending are all vaccinated. The policy is in place for the duration of the state of alert. The state of alert is slated to end on June 11, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Due to the recent decrease in COVID-19 cases, the Government of Romania announced new relaxation measures.  The new restrictions generally increase capacity and participant limits for public and private events, restaurants and resorts, and other entertainment activities.  In general, events and venues may accommodate clients at full capacity if all participants are vaccinated.  Otherwise, the measures reflect a gradual relaxation of restrictions. They include the following:  Private events (weddings, baptisms, and birthdays) may accommodate a maximum of 70 guests outdoor, 50 guests indoor, or unlimited guests if those attending are all vaccinated.  Restaurants and cafés may open between 0500-2400 at 70% capacity or full capacity if all guests are vaccinated.  Gyms and fitness facilities may open at 70% capacity with seven meters distance between clients or full capacity if all clients are vaccinated.  In certain localities with low incident rates, masks may not be required.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From September 17, 2021, the Cluj County Committee for Emergency Situations (CJSU) decided to impose several restrictions in Cluj-Napoca and the communes of Floresti and Săvădisla after the 14-day COVID-19 incidence rate increased to over 2 per thousand inhabitants.

There is a capacity limit of 50% for sports competitions held in closed or open spaces. Organizers also have to ensure a distance of at least 1 meter between participants, and people can attend these events only if they show proof of vaccination, a negative test, or proof of a previous COVID-19 infection.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
city: Cluj-Napoca and the communes of Floresti and Săvădisla
type_sub_cat: Single Recreational or commercial event allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Cluj-Napoca and the communes of Floresti and Săvădisla

description:
From September 17, 2021, in Cluj-Napoca and the communes of Floresti and Săvădisla, there is a capacity limit of 70% for cinemas or concert/theatre halls.

The number of people allowed to attend weddings, baptisms or other private events differs depending on how many participants are vaccinated. For example, a maximum of 150 people can participate if the event is held outdoors, and only 100 if the event takes place in a closed space, without any restrictions related to vaccination but in compliance with the sanitary rules. The number can increase if the participants are vaccinated or show proof of a negative test or previous infection.

description:
Starting from October 9, only people vaccinated with the full schedule ( from the tenth day of vaccination), and those who are between the 15th and 180th day after confirmation of infection with the SARS-CoV virus -2 , they will have access to certain activities and will be able to participate in certain events, such as:

- to participate in recreational and sports activities carried out outdoors, for no more than 10 people who do not live together.

description:
Romania, March 21, 2020:
The Ministry of Internal Affairs enacts that "[t]he authorities of the local public administration have the duty to locate and perform a census of
persons aged 65 and over, without support or any form of aid, and to ensure their support in order to minimize their exposure outside their households".
The policy has no explicit end date.

enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Romania, March 21, 2020:
The Ministry of Internal Affairs enacts that "[t]he authorities of the local public administration have the duty to locate and perform a census of
persons aged 65 and over, without support or any form of aid, and to ensure their support in order to minimize their exposure outside their households".
The policy has no explicit end date. UPDATE: With the repeal of the state of emergency and replacement with a "state of alert," the restrictions on elderly leaving the home end. However, the government continues to recommend caution and moreover asks local governments to continue to supply and assist the elderly (see previous notes) at home. This is further reinforced by a line in the later renewal of the order on June 16 on LTCF, which states that "Residential social service providers shall organize their program according to the existing epidemiological context at local level and in compliance with the rules in force on labor legislation. The activity at the level of these services will be organized and carried out in compliance with the rules for preventing the spread of the SARS-CoV-2 virus established by the competent authorities."     Therefore 1G maintained.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Previous restrictions of elderly being allowed outside for only two hours a day (1100-1300) are replaced by a 7-hour window, split into mornings and evenings (07.00-11.00 and 19.00-22.00). Measure starts taking effect on April 28.

description: From May 15th 2020 in Romania, private businesses/ economic operators are obliged to ensure that employers can work from home. If the work can not be performed from home then employers must not allow the access of the persons whose body temperature, measured at the entrance to the enclosure exceeds 37.3 degrees. Employers must enforce mandatory disinfection of hands before entering work spaces, and disinfection of surfaces.

description: According to the approved calendar, on June 2, students from the VIIIth and XIIth grades will come to prepare for the national exams. As such, we have a situation, per school, of the number of students who have shown this agreement to come without endangering family members, themselves or those they come into contact with. The training will be daily, in each school, respecting the distancing rules and the latest orders that provide for the provision of a 4 square meter area for each student in the classrooms, after which, from June 15, the national exams begin. Not only the children, but also the teaching, teaching-auxiliary and non-teaching staff can safely come to school, all measures will be taken, the surfaces will be disinfected by a professional company and the school staff, the materials are provided, we have additional masks, parents should not have any fear in leaving their children at school during this period.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Romania’s government plans to introduce new measures to help try to contain a spike in coronavirus cases, including shortening working hours for outdoor pubs and restaurants. description:
Romania, July 31, 2020:
The Government of Romania enacts that individuals have to wear a face mask in commercial spaces, public transport, at work and in other enclosed spaces. Local authorities may also oblige individuals from 5 upwards to wear a face mask in certain outdoor public spaces, such as markets, at certain time intervals. The policy is in place for the duration of the state of alert.

description:

- Republicii str. and Piaţa Sfatului, from Monday to Friday, between 12:00 and 23:00, and Saturday and Sunday between 10:00 and 23:00 - RATBV
stations
- bus stations
- CFR stations
- boarding and disembarking areas for cable transport
- Zoo
- all agricultural markets and fairs.

Children under the age of 5 are exempted from the obligation to wear a protective mask

description:
Romania, September 15, 2020:
The Government of Romania enacts that individuals have to wear a face mask in commercial spaces, public transport, at work and in other enclosed spaces. Local authorities may also oblige individuals from 5 upwards to wear a face mask in certain outdoor public spaces, such as markets, at certain time intervals. Face covering measures now also explicitly apply to candidates and campaign teams during events/meetings/actions related to election campaigns and to the participants in the electoral process as per article 4, section 1, number 2 of the source document. 
The policy is in place for the duration of the state of alert. The state of alert is slated to end on October 14, 2020.

description:
in addition to Republicii street and Piața Sfatului, where wearing a mask has become mandatory since August 1, starting tomorrow, October 8, this obligation will also be extended for pedestrians traveling on Mureșenilor, Apollonia Hirscher and Aleea de Sub Tâmpa streets, according to the following schedule: – Str. Mureseni: Monday - Friday, between 12.00 and 23.00; Saturday and Sunday, between 10.00 and 23.00; – Str. Apollonia Hirscher: Monday - Friday between 12.00 and 23.00; Saturday and Sunday, between 10.00 and 23.00; - Aleea Tiberiu Brediceanu, Monday - Friday between 16.00 - 19.00, Saturday and Sunday, between 10.00 - 19.00.
In addition, all those waiting to enter public institutions, shops, medical offices, analysis laboratories, banks, etc. are obliged to wear a protective mask in the waiting area outside, regardless of the area of ​​the city in which it is.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
All premises intended for public catering, bars, cafes, etc. from the Municipality of Brașov have the obligation to repeat the following social distancing measures within them against the backdrop of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic:

The economic agent will apply a sticker on the entrance door of the respective space specifying the number of people who can benefit from the services offered and which cannot be greater than half of the number of places declared when issuing the operating authorization, but not more of 50 seats, according to the attached integral part of this decision.
When setting up the furniture necessary for carrying out the commercial activity, social distancing will be respected, the existence of different entry and exit routes, according to the provisions established at the national level by the competent authorities in this regard.
Inside the premises, all rules of hygiene, disinfectant, wearing a mask, etc., will be respected, according to the provisions established at national level by the competent authorities in this regard.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Physical distancing measures continue during the State of Alert (i.e. since 15 May; see Transition measures: Governance). Borders remain closed for foreign citizens and the stateless, with some exceptions: family members of Romanian citizens, EU-EEA citizens with residence or long-term visa, diplomats, international organizations personnel, transit and emergencies. For the Romanian citizens who return to the country, the authorities may organize special transport. People with temporary working contracts abroad may travel abroad, and the recruiting agencies can organize special road or air transport.

description: Starting on June 1, outdoor concerts, public and private festivals, and other outdoor cultural events are allowed for up to 500 participants wearing face masks and observing the 2-metre physical distancing rule. Additionally, drive-in shows are permitted under specific health regulations, and only if attended by the members of the same family. Starting on June 1, outdoor sporting competitions without public attendance can be organized in compliance with detailed preventive measures. Contact sports competitions are not yet permitted.

Romania, July 31, 2020:
The Government of Romania enacts that individuals have to wear a face mask in commercial spaces, public transport, at work and in other enclosed spaces. Local authorities may also oblige individuals from 5 upwards to wear a face mask in certain outdoor public spaces, such as markets, at certain time intervals. The policy is in place for the duration of the state of alert.
Update: Face masks remain mandatory at least until August 10, 2021. All passengers must wear mask. UPDATE: Update: Face masks remain mandatory at least until August 10, 2021. All passengers must wear mask.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all indoor spaces
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Ministry of Education presents on its website real-time data regarding the number of schools following each scenario. As of September 24, 12,838 schools are providing face-to-face courses, 4,505 schools are in the hybrid model, and 313 schools provide only online teaching. Face masks, physical distancing, hands hygiene and other preventive measures are mandatory in classes.

description:
Starting October 25, 2021, public access to the premises of Brașov City Hall and its departments and services subordinate to the City Council is allowed only to people who provide proof of vaccination, passing through the disease in the last 180 days or testing, verified by means of the EU digital certificate regarding COVID-19, which will be scanned by their own staff.
In the case of RT-PCR testing, the negative result must not be more than 72 hours old, and in the case of a rapid antigen test, the result must not be more than 48 hours old.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside All government services regulated
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Starting October 25, 2021, public access to the premises of Brașov City Hall and its departments and services subordinate to the City Council is allowed only to people who provide proof of vaccination, passing through the disease in the last 180 days or testing, verified by means of the EU digital certificate regarding COVID-19, which will be scanned by their own staff. UPDATE: For urgent situations (for example: issuing a certificate of death, birth certificate) it is not necessary to present a green certificate, a proof that the person in question is in the period between the 15th and 180th day after the confirmation of infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus or a result negative in one of the COVID-19, RT-PCR or antigen tests.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On the 11th of January 2023, the Minister of Health, Alexandru Rafila, declared that no restrictions will be introduced in Romania in the context of the new wave of COVID-19 in China.
